If you think your child may have a food intolerance, keeping a food diary can reveal a pattern of symptoms that can help you to identify the culprit and is useful to show your doctor. Seeing a paediatric dietician is also worthwhile if a food intolerance is diagnosed: lactose intolerant children, for example, will need replacements for dairy products such as soya or rice based milk and they may need calcium and vitamin D supplements.

Living with a food allergy or intolerance

Once an allergy is confirmed, of course your child needs to avoid eating the food in question, but this may leave you feeling concerned about which nutrients he is missing out on. It’s worth consulting a paediatric dietician who can tell you not only what to avoid (foods can be hidden under other names in packaged products), but also how to compensate for nutritional shortfalls in his diet.

What's the outlook?

The good news is that while some allergies are usually life-long, such as a peanut allergy, others, such as dairy and egg allergies, are often outgrown during childhood. This is why the allergy specialist will consider retesting your child as he gets older to check if an allergy has receded. If this is the case, he can be gradually weaned back onto the food.

title: Cow's milk allergy
tipDescription:
One of the most common childhood food allergies is to cow’s milk, with up to 7% of infants and young children affected. 

The good news is that most children grow out of cow’s milk allergy by three to five years of age. 

What causes cow’s milk allergy?

Cow’s milk allergy occurs when the body reacts to one or more of the proteins present in cow’s milk. It usually develops in the first year of life, while the immune system is still developing, with symptoms often becoming apparent in the first weeks or months.

Susceptible babies commonly develop symptoms, or a worsening of symptoms, if they are switched from breast to formula milk, which contains cow’s milk proteins, or during the weaning process when dairy foods are introduced. 

Babies with an existing allergy, or whose families have a history of allergies, have a higher risk of developing cow’s milk allergy.

If a baby develops atopic eczema in the early weeks of life he is also at higher risk. Babies who are exclusively breastfed in the early months, are less likely to develop cow’s milk allergy, although it is possible for particularly sensitive babies to react to cow’s milk from the mother’s diet that makes its way into breast milk. 

What are the symptoms of cow’s milk allergy?

Symptoms can vary from child to child, and can also depend on the type of reaction your child has.

There are two types of allergic reaction to cow’s milk. Some infants have an almost instant reaction, with symptoms typically appearing seconds or minutes after consuming any food or drink containing milk.

If, after consuming some form of cow’s milk, your baby has any of the following symptoms – appears flushed and develops a rash around his mouth, has a stuffy nose, itchy eyes, hives (red, itchy lumps) on the body, or has vomiting or diarrhoea – he may be having an immediate reaction to cow’s milk.

This type of reaction is usually easy to spot, and often straightforward to diagnose (see below). 

Rarely, a severe reaction can cause difficulty in breathing and floppiness, known as anaphylaxis. Thankfully, this type of reaction is extremely uncommon in infants, but if it does occur, you should call an ambulance immediately. 

Some infants have a delayed reaction to cow’s milk, with symptoms appearing hours, and even days, later. Symptoms can include skin conditions such as eczema, reflux (bringing up relatively large amounts of milk), colic, diarrhoea, sometimes with mucous and blood in it, and less commonly constipation.

As symptoms are delayed and are often due to other common childhood conditions, this type of reaction is less easy to spot and diagnose. 

What should I do if I suspect a cow’s milk allergy?

If you think your child is reacting to cow’s milk, make an appointment straight away to see your GP so that your child can be assessed and if necessary a referral to a specialist can be made to organise tests to confirm an allergy.

You should not change your child’s milk or diet without professional advice.

A delayed reaction is harder to identify and symptoms can build up over time as the child is exposed repeatedly to the allergen.

If you notice a pattern to symptoms that you think could be a delayed reaction to a food, possibly cow’s milk, it’s a good idea to keep a food and symptoms diary to show your GP. Record the date and time a food was given, the amount of food, and any symptoms, stating when these occurred, how long they lasted and their severity. 

The more information you can give your GP, the easier it will be for them to spot any patterns and work out the best course of action.

As well as providing a food and symptoms diary, be ready to discuss your child’s symptoms in detail, including when they first started, how quickly they developed and whether they vary. Your GP may also ask whether your baby, or your baby’s family, have other allergic conditions such as asthma and eczema.

You are likely to have plenty of questions for your GP, which can be easy to forget during a busy appointment. To make the best use of your appointment time, write down any questions you have beforehand so you can be happy that you’ve covered all your concerns and queries.

Making a diagnosis

Your GP may refer your baby to a specialist allergy clinic where investigations and tests will be carried out to identify whether a food allergy is causing your baby’s symptoms.

If you think that your baby has an instant reaction to cow’s milk, then a blood or skin-prick test may be able to establish this quickly. This may sound a little alarming, but actually both procedures are relatively painless for your baby.

A simple heel-prick test can provide enough blood for testing. With a skin-prick test, a small drop of cow’s milk is placed on the skin, and then the skin is gently pricked. If a red bump, or weal, appears, this confirms the allergy. 

Diagnosing delayed reactions is less straightforward as skin prick and blood tests are of little use.

Your doctor or the clinic is likely to recommend an exclusion diet, where you completely eliminate cow’s milk from your child’s diet, or from yours if you’re breastfeeding.

This should be carried out under the guidance of a qualified dietician. It’s very important to always seek medical guidance before attempting an exclusion diet to ensure that your baby doesn’t miss out on nutrients vital for his growth and well-being.

If cow’s milk is the culprit, symptoms should improve within a two to four weeks. A food “challenge” will then be done, whereby cow’s milk is gradually reintroduced into the diet to see if symptoms recur, which confirms the allergy.

What happens after a diagnosis?

Once a cow’s milk allergy is confirmed you will be advised to continue on the exclusion diet for at least five months, or until your child is one year old. After this cow’s milk will gradually be reintroduced into your child’s diet to see if he has outgrown the allergy.

Talk to your GP and/or dietician about managing your child’s diet. 

If your baby has formula milk, your GP can prescribe a special type of formula, known as fully hydrolysed formula, where the milk proteins are broken down to make them easier for your baby to digest.

Some babies may still experience symptoms, in which case an amino acid based formula may be prescribed that doesn’t contain any cow’s milk proteins. 

Don’t be tempted to switch to other infant milks, such as soya milk, without talking to your doctor or health visitor first.

Soya milk isn’t recommended under six months of age, and infants who are allergic to cow’s milk may also develop an allergy to soya. Likewise, susceptible infants are also likely to react to proteins in sheep or goats’ milk.

Oat milk will not provide all the nutrients your baby needs for growth, and rice milk isn’t recommended for children under four and a half years old. Fully hydrolysed formula is usually preferable to these alternatives.

Can I continue breastfeeding?

It’s recommended that you continue breastfeeding as breast milk has countless benefits for your baby, including providing antibodies that strengthen his immune system. Talk to a health professional about how to eliminate milk products from your own diet without missing out on important nutrients.

Managing weaning with cow’s milk allergy

If your baby is ready to wean, or has already started on solid foods, a dietician can guide you on how to introduce new foods and which foods to avoid.

The list of foods to avoid will include weaning staples such as cheese, yoghurt and butter, as well as hidden sources of cow’s milk in foods such as processed meats, cakes and biscuits. It’s important that your baby gets used to a variety of textures and flavours while he is being weaned to make sure he has adequate nutrition and doesn’t become a fussy eater.

A dietician will guide you on how to ensure your baby receives a diet that meets his nutritional and energy needs. 

When an allergy is present, parents often worry about introducing other common allergenic foods, such as eggs and wheat, into their child’s diet.

There are no official guidelines to avoid these, and they provide important nutrients. The best thing is to talk to your healthcare professional before giving these foods to your baby, who can advise you on how to introduce these foods gradually, trying one at a time and keeping an eye out for reactions. 

What’s the outlook for my child?

Most children outgrow cow’s milk allergy during infancy, although for some the allergy continues into their teenage years.

After 12 months of age, your child should have regular check-ups, ideally around every six months to monitor his growth and general health and assess any symptoms. 

If an allergy continues during childhood, a paediatric dietician can provide continued support, advising you on all the milk protein alternatives on the market to ensure your child receives adequate sources of calcium, protein and other important nutrients to meet his changing needs as he grows. 

As your child gets older it may be appropriate to try a controlled food challenge to see if cow’s milk can be gradually reintroduced into the diet. You will be given advice on this by your healthcare professional.

What’s the difference between lactose intolerance and cow’s milk allergy?

These two conditions can both cause bowel symptoms but have quite different causes. Where cow’s milk allergy involves the immune system, which overreacts to one or more of the proteins in milk, lactose intolerance occurs when the body lacks the enzyme lactase, which is needed to digest the sugar, lactose, in milk.

The enzyme may be deficient from birth, although this is rare, or it may develop gradually throughout childhood and adolescence. In the latter case, symptoms do not usually occurring before the age or two or three years.

A temporary form of lactose intolerance can develop after a gastrointestinal infection and the condition improves once the gut lining begins to heal. Symptoms can include bloating, wind, diarrhoea and abdominal pain.

Lactose intolerance is managed by avoiding milk and dairy products that contain lactose. As with cow’s milk allergy, it is important to seek professional advice before changing your child’s milk or diet.
